__data__.text: Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, Spain, is situated on a 102.16 km² plain near the Mediterranean coast, with its northeast side bordering the Collserola mountain range and its highest point at Tibidabo (516.2 m). Montjuïc mountain (184.8 m) is above the coastline, and several hills run parallel to the coastal range. The plain, which is not flat but has undulations due to historical torrents, has a general slope towards Collserola with a 260 m elevation change. Two major fault lines exist, one between Collserola and the parallel hills, and another between Montjuïc and the coast. The ground consists of slate, granite, clay, and limestone. The coast, once covered in salt-water lagoons and tidal marshes, extended 5 km since the 6th century BC due to river sediment.

Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, Spain, is situated on a hilly plain near the Mediterranean coast, with its highest point at Tibidabo (516.2 m). The terrain's substrate is made up of slate, granite, clay, and limestone, with the coast extending 5 km since the 6th century BC due to river sediment. The city has a Mediterranean climate with mild winters and low rainfall, historically necessitating water supply works. The area was once used for rainfed and irrigated agriculture, mainly vineyards and cereals, but is now mostly built up. Barcelona is the most significant urban center in Catalonia, serving as the seat of the autonomous government, parliament, and various other important institutions. It is Spain's second most populous city and the eleventh most populous in the European Union.

Barcelona, the second largest city in Spain and eleventh in the EU, is the capital of Catalonia and serves as an important political and institutional hub, housing the autonomous government, parliament, provincial deputation, archbishopric, and IV Military Region. It has a population of 1.6 million and is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods, including Ciutat Vella and Eixample. Ciutat Vella, the oldest part of the city, was once a major center for immigration from other parts of Spain and is now a significant tourist attraction with numerous monuments and institutions such as the City Hall and Generalitat de Catalunya. Eixample, on the other hand, was developed as a residential area for wealthy families after the demolition of the city walls and is now primarily inhabited by the middle class.

Barcelona's districts vary in their historical development, population, and character. Eixample, once a residential area for the wealthy, is now a middle-class district known for its modernist architecture and commercial activity. Sants-Montjuïc, the largest district, includes the old town of Sants and Montjuïc mountain, has a lower population density, and a higher percentage of green area and foreign residents. Les Corts, a former agricultural area, is now primarily middle-class with a significant number of young people and financial institutions. Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, formed by the union of two former municipalities, is the largest and least densely populated district, with a high-status residential area, quality facilities, and private schools.

Barcelona's districts have diverse historical development, population, and character. Sarrià-Sant Gervasi is one of the largest and least densely populated districts, with a high-status residential area, quality facilities, and private schools. It has a highly educated population and a predominantly autochthonous European Union foreign population. Gràcia, once an agricultural area, has a high population density with narrow streets and tightly packed houses. It has a higher percentage of elderly residents and a lower-middle social class population. Horta-Guinardó, also originating from an agricultural area, has a low population density and is predominantly young and lower-middle class. It experienced real estate speculation and high immigration in the first two thirds of the 20th century. Nou Barris is the most recently created district with a majority immigrant population, low purchasing power, and a history of shantyism and self-construction. Sant Andreu corresponds to the former municipality of Sant Andreu de Palomar, annexed in 1897.

Barcelona's districts, Sant Andreu and Sant Martí, have experienced agricultural and milling history, followed by industrialization and immigration. Sant Andreu, previously an agricultural and milling area, transformed into an industrial zone in the mid-nineteenth century and later received a significant wave of immigration in the mid-twentieth century. It has undergone recent revitalization due to commercial activities and urbanization. Sant Martí, also an agricultural and milling area, saw numerous factories during the Industrial Revolution, followed by deindustrialization and a shift towards technology-based economic activities. It also welcomed a large immigrant population and experienced renovation during the 1992 Olympic Games. Historically, the city was divided into four quarters in 1389, reflecting social differences between the neighborhoods.

The city of Barcelona was initially divided into four quarters in 1389, distinguishing social differences among neighborhoods. The northern quarters, Framenors, were aristocratic, while Pi was residential and civil service. Sant Pere was industrial and commercial, and Mar was popular and religious, hosting many convents and monasteries. A fifth quarter, Raval, was added in the 15th century. In 1769, the city was reorganized into five quarters, each with eight neighborhoods. The divisions changed multiple times in the 19th century for political reasons, as districts also served as electoral districts. The text highlights that Sant Andreu and Sant Martí experienced agricultural, milling, industrialization, immigration, and revitalization phases, while the city itself has undergone several historical divisions, reflecting social and political changes.

The text describes how the city of Barcelona has been divided into various districts and neighborhoods throughout its history, reflecting social and political changes. Notable divisions occurred in 1837, 1878, and the early 20th century, with the addition of neighboring municipalities and adjustments to the number of districts. In 1933, the city was reorganized into ten districts, and two more were added in 1949. The current division into ten districts was approved in 1984 to decentralize the City Council and ensure residents have access to a wide range of services, while respecting the historical and morphological identity of each district.

In 1949, Barcelona's districts expanded to include XI-Les Corts and XII-Sagrada Família. A major reorganization in 1984 divided the city into ten districts to decentralize the City Council and provide better services, while respecting historical and morphological identities. Some areas, like Pedralbes, Vallcarca, El Guinardó, and parts of Sant Andreu, were reassigned to different districts. The most recent reform in 2006 established 73 neighborhoods, following historical, cultural, and social criteria, causing controversy due to the fragmentation of some historical neighborhoods and unfulfilled aspirations of others. Barcelona's history traces back to its founding as Barcino by Roman colonizers in the first century BC, initially as a small walled city on Mons Taber hill, presently Plaça de Sant Jaume.

Barcelona was established as Barcino by Roman colonizers in the first century BC, initially as a small walled city on Mons Taber hill, now Plaça de Sant Jaume. The city's growth peaked in the second century, hosting around 3500-5000 inhabitants. The location was chosen for its natural harbor, although the harbor's depth became problematic over time due to alluvium and sand sedimentation. The city center was the forum, situated at the intersection of the cardus maximus and decumanus maximus, shaping the city's orthogonal layout. The Romans engineered roads, bridges, aqueducts, and an orderly urban design with basic services like sewerage. The initial wall, built in the first century BC, was expanded in the 4th century due to external threats.

Barcelona's initial wall, constructed in the first century BC, was modest with few towers. After invasions by Frankish and Alemanni tribes in the 250s, the wall was reinforced and expanded in the 4th century to include a double wall with 74 towers. The Roman city was repurposed as a military stronghold in the ensuing centuries, with feudal colonization of surrounding areas and emergence of suburbs. Barcelona eventually became the capital of the Catalan counties and a significant maritime and commercial hub in the Mediterranean Sea as part of the Crown of Aragon during the Middle Ages. The city expanded from its original core, the Gothic Quarter, and the Raval district emerged in the 14th century. Roman urban elements like necropolises and aqueducts were preserved, with tombs and remnants found in Plaça de la Vila de Madrid and Plaça Nova.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona, starting from its original core (the Gothic Quarter), experienced growth and became a county and later a part of the Crown of Aragon, becoming a significant political, economic, and maritime hub in the Mediterranean Sea. The city's expansion led to the emergence of the Raval district and an increase in population to around 25,000 inhabitants. After being nearly destroyed in 985, Barcelona was rebuilt upon its Roman foundations, gaining autonomy and developing a complex network of social and institutional relations. The Council of One Hundred was established in 1265 to manage the city's administration, overseeing public services, urban planning, and demarcation. The Jewish quarter, the Call, existed between Ferran, Banys Nous, Palla, and Bisbe streets until its destruction in 1391 due to xenophobic violence.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona underwent expansion and established its first urban layout, known as Consuetuds de Santacilia, as outlined by James I. The city had a Jewish quarter, the Call, situated between Ferran, Banys Nous, Palla, and Bisbe streets until its destruction in 1391 due to xenophobic violence. The Call had two synagogues, baths, schools, and hospitals, separated from the rest of the city by a wall. Agricultural development thrived outside the city walls, particularly in the hort i vinyet de Barcelona, which produced fruits, vegetables, and wine. The area was irrigated by two canals constructed in the 10th century, directing the waters of the Llobregat and Besòs rivers to the city's vicinity. After the threat of Muslim incursions ceased, population centers emerged outside the city walls, near churches and monasteries, such as Santa Maria del Mar, Sant Cugat del Rec, Sant Pere, Santa Maria del Pi, Santa Anna, Portal del Bisbe, and Mercadal.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona expanded beyond its initial urban layout with the emergence of new neighborhoods like the Raval, which was originally a suburb with orchards and religious buildings. As the city grew, a new wall was constructed in 1260, extending from Sant Pere de les Puelles to the Drassanes, adding 5100 meters and 1.5 km² of fortified area with eighty towers and eight new gates. The Raval neighborhood contained several significant religious buildings, such as the monastery of Sant Pau del Camp and the church of Sant Antoni Abat.

The medieval urban fabric was divided into various areas of influence, including aristocracy, institutional power, the bishopric, religious orders, guilds, and trade associations. The street network was irregular, and houses were typically "artisan type," with a workshop on the first floor and living quarters on the upper floors, averaging 4 meters wide and 10-12 meters deep, sometimes with a small vegetable garden at the back. The Raval neighborhood, initially an independent suburb, became integrated into the expanding city within the newly constructed walls.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona underwent urban expansion with the emergence of new neighborhoods and the construction of new walls. The Raval neighborhood, initially an independent suburb, became integrated into the city and featured artisan-type houses, typically 4 meters wide and 10-12 meters deep, with some having small vegetable gardens. The street network was irregular, and squares were derived from demolished houses. Major buildings included churches, palaces, institutional buildings, and hospitals. Notable urban planning operations included the creation of Montcada street in 1209 and Plaça Nova in 1355. A new wall, the Raval wall, was constructed in the 14th-15th centuries, adding a 6 km perimeter and enclosing a 218 ha area, which included a long avenue called La Rambla.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona experienced urban growth, resulting in the construction of new neighborhoods like Raval and walls, with major buildings such as churches and hospitals. The Raval wall, built in the 14th-15th centuries, enclosed a larger area with La Rambla as its primary avenue. By the Early Modern Age, Barcelona was part of the Hispanic Monarchy, with periods of prosperity and crisis. Large-scale urban projects were rare due to the loss of capital status, except for the sea wall's construction in the 16th century. The city's population neared 100,000 by the end of this period, but urban reforms were minimal, with growth mainly happening in La Barceloneta. Road networks connected Barcelona to nearby suburbs, villages, and points of interest.

During the 15th and 16th centuries, Barcelona constructed an artificial port to address its growing maritime trade, which had been hampered by the lack of a suitable port facility. The new port, completed in the mid-16th century, featured a 180-meter-long quay and improved water supply and sewage systems. The seafront between Pla de Palau and La Rambla was embanked, creating the Passeig del Mar (now Passeig de Colom). Additionally, the city extended its walls by building five new gates in the 17th century. Concurrently, urban development continued with the construction of the sea wall, including bastions such as Llevant, Torre Nova, Sant Ramon, and Migdia, and the opening of the Plaça de la Seu and Plaça de San Iu near the cathedral.

In the 15th and 16th centuries, Barcelona developed a new port to facilitate maritime trade, which included a 180-meter-long quay and enhanced water and sewage systems. The city also extended its walls and constructed urban elements such as paved streets, sewers, and drinking water fountains. However, during the 18th century, the Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona lost much of their autonomy due to the Nueva Planta Decree, which replaced the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent with a military government. The economy became increasingly industrialized, and the population grew significantly. The Bourbons initiated several military engineering projects, including the castle of Montjuïc and the fortress of the Citadel, which required the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, leaving 4500 people homeless. Additionally, two new military roads were constructed, and the neighborhood of La Barceloneta was built on a small peninsula, showcasing academic baroque urbanism.

During the 18th century, Barcelona underwent significant urban development, including the creation of the neighborhood of La Barceloneta on a small peninsula, designed with a grid of orthogonal streets and elongated houses, exemplifying academic baroque urbanism. The Edicto de obreria ordinance was introduced to regulate private construction, such as aligning houses with street layouts, paving, sewage, and house numbering, requiring building permits and fees. A height limit for buildings was established in 1797. The typology of private buildings evolved from medieval artisan houses to multi-family houses with collective staircases, separating work and residence. The redevelopment of La Rambla, an ancient torrent and western city boundary, was carried out between 1776-1778, demolishing the inner wall, realigning buildings, and creating a landscaped promenade. Other projects included the paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia, and the street of the Count of the Assault (now New Street of La Rambla).

The paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia were developed in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, along with the street of the Count of the Assault (now New Street of La Rambla). The Paseo Nuevo or Paseo de la Explanada was also created next to the military Citadel, serving as the city's main green space until its disappearance during urbanization works. During the 18th century, the Born and Boqueria markets were established, and aspects like weights and measures for food products were regulated.

The 19th century brought significant economic revitalization, mainly due to the textile industry, which led to a Catalan cultural renaissance. The city walls were demolished between 1854 and 1859, allowing urban expansion under the Eixample project by Ildefons Cerdà. After the 1868 revolution, the Citadel was demolished and transformed into a public park. The population grew to 400,000 inhabitants by the end of the century.

Industrialization began in earnest with the founding of the Bonaplata Factory in 1832 and the La España Industrial complex in 1849. The textile industry flourished until a crisis in 1861 due to cotton shortages from the American Civil War. The metallurgical industry also gained importance, driven by the creation of the railroad and steam navigation.

The La España Industrial complex was established in 1849 by the Muntadas brothers, contributing to the growth of the textile industry until a crisis in 1861 due to the American Civil War's cotton shortages. The metallurgical industry also thrived, driven by the railroad and steam navigation. Industrialization led to significant urban planning changes in Barcelona, including population influx, linked industrial and urban developments, and improved transportation. Municipal ordinances were consolidated, starting with the Edicto de obrería in 1814, and the Pregón de policía urbana in 1839, which regulated various aspects of urban living and building design. The first Ordenanzas Municipales were approved in 1856, integrating and expanding previous provisions, and introducing building permit requirements with interior layout plans.

The first Municipal Ordinances were established in 1856, consolidating and expanding previous regulations and requiring interior layout plans for building permits. However, these ordinances quickly became outdated due to the new Eixample plan in 1891, which increased the plot occupation area to 70%. Significant urban planning actions during this time included the opening of Calle de Fernando, the expansion of the Pla de Palau, and the construction of the Portal de Mar, which were all later demolished. These developments were driven by industrialization and aimed to accommodate population growth and improve transportation.

The urban planning in the mid-19th century was influenced by factors such as industrialization, population growth, and new sanitary provisions. The Pla de Palau expansion began in 1833, leading to the construction of the Portal de Mar (1844-1848), which was later demolished in 1859 along with the city walls. A widening plan in 1838, which included the creation of Plaça de Catalunya, was never completed. The confiscation of 1836 resulted in the development of public spaces like La Boqueria and Santa Catalina markets, the Gran Teatro del Liceo (Liceu), and two squares by Francesc Daniel Molina. New sanitary regulations led to the disappearance of parish cemeteries and the creation of new cemeteries outside the city, such as the cemetery of the East or Pueblo Nuevo (Poblenou) in 1819 and the Southwest or Montjuic cemetery in 1883. The gas lighting, a symbol of modernity, was introduced in 1842 due to new scientific advances.

The urban planning of Barcelona in the mid-19th century saw the development of new infrastructure due to factors such as industrialization, population growth, and sanitary regulations. The first gas lighting was introduced in 1842, and the first railroad line in peninsular Spain was established in 1848, connecting Barcelona with Mataró. This led to the creation of several train stations and the development of Barcelona as a metropolitan area. In the 1880s, links with France, Madrid, Zaragoza, and Valencia were established. The first fire and police services, such as the Guardia Urbana de Barcelona and the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona, also emerged during this time. The Southwest or Montjuic cemetery was built in 1883, followed by the North or Collserola cemetery in 1969.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona experienced significant urban development due to industrialization, population growth, and sanitary regulations. The city's first public fire department, the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona, was established in 1865, taking over from the private Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios. The first chief was Antoni Rovira i Trias, and the department initially operated from the Casa de Comunes Depósitos. In 1908, animal-drawn vehicles were replaced by motor vehicles, and firefighters became professionalized in 1913. The city also improved its infrastructure, with new road layouts such as the Sarrià road, the road from Sants to Les Corts, and the road from Sagrera to Horta. The port was expanded with a new wharf and dredging in 1859. Additionally, the telegraph service began in 1855, controlled by the State and later incorporated into the postal service. The first public parks also appeared in the 19th century due to the environmental degradation caused by industrialization.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona underwent significant urban development due to industrialization, population growth, and sanitary concerns. The city's first public garden, the General's Garden, was established in 1816 by Captain General Francisco Javier Castaños, but it disappeared in 1877 during the development of the park of the Citadel. Other gardens, such as the Tívoli Gardens (1848) and the Champs Elysées (1853), were also built but disappeared with the urbanization of Passeig de Gràcia.

A major event in Barcelona's expansion was the demolition of the city walls in 1854, which had become a health hazard due to the increasing population density (850 inhabitants per hectare). The walls' demolition allowed for the city's territorial expansion, and in 1859, the City Council held a competition for urban expansion projects, which was won by Antoni Rovira i Trias. However, the Ministry of Development intervened and imposed Ildefons Cerdà's project, the author of a topographic plan of the Barcelona plain and a demographic and urbanistic study of the city (1855).

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona experienced significant urban development, leading to the creation of the Cerdà Plan in 1859. This plan introduced an orthogonal layout for the city, with wide streets (20m) arranged in a grid pattern, intersecting at right angles. The design included open spaces for gardens, although this was not fully realized, and buildings were to have an octagonal shape with chamfers for better circulation. Major avenues, such as Diagonal, Meridiana, Paral·lel, Gran Via, and Passeig de Sant Joan, were planned, along with large squares at their intersections.

The Cerdà Plan also envisioned new roads in the old city, connecting the Eixample with the coast and Montjuic, and a series of ring roads around the city. The project was innovative, focusing on functional, recreational, and welfare aspects, with building heights set at 16m and depths between 10-20m. Each neighborhood was to have a church, civic center, school, daycare, nursing home, and other welfare facilities, while each district would have a market and each sector a park. Industrial and administrative facilities, as well as a slaughterhouse, cemetery, and three hospitals, were also included in the suburbs.

The Cerdà Plan, implemented in mid-19th century Barcelona, aimed to create a well-planned city with an orthogonal layout, wide streets, and open spaces for gardens. The plan included provisions for neighborhood churches, civic centers, schools, daycare, nursing homes, district markets, and sector parks. Additionally, it accounted for industrial and administrative facilities, as well as a slaughterhouse, cemetery, and three hospitals in the suburbs. However, many of these features were not realized due to opposition from the City Council and real estate speculation. Cerdà's urbanistic theory focused on hygienism, circulation, and multipurpose design, aiming to improve living conditions, ensure compatibility between pedestrians and vehicles, and create a functional city. The plan often overlapped with existing or developing suburban layouts and had to accommodate the urban projects of neighboring towns.

The Cerdà Plan, implemented in mid-19th century Barcelona, aimed to create a well-planned city with an orthogonal layout, accounting for various facilities and open spaces. However, many features were not realized due to opposition and speculation. The plan had to consider existing or developing suburban layouts and land features. A new toponymy was established for the streets in the new urban grid, inspired by Catalonia's history.

As the plan was mainly implemented outside the city walls, an "interior renovations" project was proposed to modernize the old core of the expanding city. Miquel Garriga i Roca's project in 1862 aimed to realign streets, but it was not executed due to difficulties and the absence of expropriation mechanisms. Àngel Baixeras's project in 1878, with an approved expropriation bill in 1879, was more elaborate and successful in its execution.

The Cerdà Plan's interior renovation project, initially proposed by Miquel Garriga i Roca in 1862 to realign streets, was not executed due to difficulties and the lack of expropriation mechanisms. Àngel Baixeras's project in 1878, with an approved expropriation bill in 1879, was more successful. Baixeras's plan aimed for a comprehensive remodeling of the old city, including the creation of three major walkable thoroughfares. However, it was not approved until 1895 and only partially realized, with the construction of Vía Laietana. During this period, urban transport evolved from omnibuses to horse-drawn tramways and eventually to electrified streetcars in 1899. Street furniture also became more prevalent, driven by advances in iron industry and the installation of electric lighting in the 1880s.

During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the growth of the iron industry led to the proliferation of street furniture such as lampposts, fountains, and benches, which were more robust and durable due to mass production. The installation of electric lighting began in the 1880s, with the first electric street lamps appearing in Plaça de Sant Jaume, and the generalization of electric light occurring in the early 1900s with the invention of the light bulb. The first telephone communication in the Iberian Peninsula took place in Barcelona in 1877, and the city saw a significant increase in the number of telephones, from 2479 in 1897 to 850,000 in 2000. Additionally, many supply markets were constructed, many of them made of iron, reflecting the architectural trends of the time.

During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the iron industry's growth resulted in robust and durable street furniture, including the construction of numerous supply markets, such as the markets of Born, Sant Antoni, Hostafrancs, La Barceloneta, Concepción, Llibertat, Clot, Unió, Gràcia, and Sants. The 1888 Universal Exposition, held in Barcelona, had a significant impact on the city, leading to improvements in infrastructure and modernization. The Exposition took place in the Citadel Park, which was remodeled with extensive gardens, a central square, a ring road, a monumental fountain, ornamental elements, two lakes, a wooded area, auxiliary buildings, and infrastructures. The Salón de San Juan was also remodeled, featuring wrought iron balustrades, pavement mosaics, and large lampposts.

The 1888 Universal Exposition in Barcelona led to significant urban improvements, including the remodeling of the Citadel Park with wrought iron balustrades, pavement mosaics, and large lampposts, all designed by Pere Falqués. Many Exposition buildings were removed after the event, but some structures, like the Castle of the Three Dragons and the Museum of Natural Sciences of Barcelona, remained. The city underwent major changes, including the urbanization of the seafront, the beginning of the Plaça de Catalunya project, the creation of the Rambla de Catalunya, and the start of Avenue of Paral·lel and Passeig de Sant Joan's extension. Pere Garcia Fària's sewage system project from 1891 also had a lasting impact, implementing a unitary system for rainwater and wastewater, and expanding the sewerage network from 31.2 km to 212 km.

The 1888 Universal Exposition in Barcelona resulted in urban improvements, including the remodeling of the Citadel Park and the creation of new infrastructure. A unitary system for rainwater and wastewater, designed by Pere Garcia Fària, was implemented, expanding the sewerage network from 31.2 km to 212 km. Additionally, the city's streets were paved with tiles and cobblestones, replaced by asphalt in the 1960s. The increase in population during the 19th and 20th centuries led to higher water consumption, requiring a larger water collection and distribution network. A new pipeline was constructed from Dosrius, and marketing companies, such as Sociedad General de Aguas de Barcelona (AGBAR), were established. The Eixample area was progressively urbanized through private initiative and the creation of new hospitals, including the Hospital Clínico y Provincial and the Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau. The urbanization process involved several phases, including filling the area, parceling the land, installing services, and constructing buildings.

The 1879 Law of Forced Expropriation served as the basis for urban development in the 20th century, which featured a management system combining public and private efforts. Urbanization occurred in phases, including land filling, parceling, installing services, and building. During this time, most homes were rental properties, with owners occupying the second floor and renting the rest.

The 20th century was marked by political instability, including the end of the monarchy, the Second Republic, the Civil War, Franco's dictatorship, and the reestablishment of the monarchy and democracy. Socially, Barcelona experienced significant immigration and population growth, peaking at 1.75 million in the 1970-1980 period and stabilizing around 1.5 million by the end of the century.

In response to the loss of American and Asian colonies and the rise of the Regionalist League, politicians and architects, such as Francesc Cambó, Enric Prat de la Riba, and Josep Puig i Cadafalch, aimed to elevate Barcelona to the level of international cities like Paris, New York, Berlin, and Vienna. They proposed models like "Imperial Barcelona" and "Nova París del Migdia." Consequently, infrastructure, railroads, transport, equipment, free port creation, industrial society needs, population increase accommodations, and improvements in education, culture, and green spaces became priorities. The period saw the implementation of Municipal Aggregations and the Plan of Connections.

In the early 20th century, Barcelona underwent significant expansion by annexing several neighboring towns, increasing its size from 15.5 km² to 77.8 km² and its population from 383,908 to 559,589. This growth necessitated better infrastructure and connections between the new and existing areas. In 1903, an international competition was held, won by French town planner Léon Jaussely, to create a plan for connecting the city. Jaussely's plan, which integrated the new municipalities with Barcelona and each other, prioritized organizational aspects over expansive ones. It was based on a structural scheme that differentiated various urban fabrics, reflecting the Beaux-Arts layouts popular in international environments then. During this time, there was also a focus on improving infrastructure, railroads, transport, equipment, creating a free port, addressing the needs of an industrialized society, accommodating population growth, and enhancing education, culture, and green spaces.

In the early 20th century, Barcelona expanded and integrated several neighboring towns, leading to the need for better infrastructure and connections. A 1903 competition won by French town planner Léon Jaussely resulted in a plan that focused on organizational aspects and differentiated various urban fabrics, aligning with international Beaux-Arts layouts. Jaussely's plan, only partially realized, emphasized three main criteria: a road scheme with main axes, zoning of activities, and systematization of green spaces. It included large road infrastructures, parks, rail links, public buildings, and facilities. The Via Laietana, a significant action during this period, connected the Eixample with the sea and was completed in 1908 with a uniform, noucentista appearance influenced by the Chicago School. Jaussely's innovative ideas greatly impacted Barcelona's urban planning throughout the century.

In the early 1900s, Barcelona underwent expansion and integrated nearby towns, requiring improved infrastructure and connections. A 1903 competition won by Léon Jaussely resulted in a partial implementation of his urban plan, focusing on organization, distinguishing urban fabrics, and emphasizing a road scheme with main axes, zoning of activities, and systematization of green spaces. The Via Laietana, completed in 1908, was a significant result of this period, featuring a uniform, noucentista appearance influenced by the Chicago School.

During this time, the city also urbanized Tibidabo's slopes, creating a wide avenue with single-family homes inspired by English garden cities, a tramway, and two funiculars. The Can Muntaner estate, an unsuccessful garden city project led by Eusebi Güell and Antoni Gaudí, was later converted into Park Güell. Additionally, the port was expanded between 1905 and 1912 with the extension of the eastern dock and the construction of a counter dock and inner docks.

In the early 1900s, Barcelona experienced growth and modernization, including the expansion of the port and the introduction of general electrification. The Barcelona Traction Light and Power company played a significant role in electrification, constructing reservoirs and power stations. This electrification led to Barcelona's industrial growth, particularly in sectors like metallurgy, chemistry, and automobiles. During this time, public urinals known as vespasianas were installed but were later removed and replaced with underground ones. The tramway network was extended, and the first bus line began operation in 1906. The Can Muntaner estate, an unsuccessful garden city project, was converted into Park Güell in 1926.

In the early 1900s, Barcelona's urban transportation system expanded with the introduction of suburban tram lines, city buses, and taxis. The first taxis emerged in 1910, and their numbers reached 1,000 by 1920. The green light was adopted as a "free" signal in 1928, and black and yellow became the city's official colors in 1931. The Barcelona Metro was constructed in the 1920s, with lines 3 and 1 opening in 1924 and 1926, respectively. The metro system has since grown to 12 lines. Initially, three companies operated the metro, but they eventually merged and combined with the bus company to form Transportes Metropolitanos de Barcelona (TMB) in 1979. During this period, public education also expanded significantly due to the efforts of the City Council, the Provincial Deputation, and the Commonwealth of Catalonia.

In the 1920s, Barcelona experienced growth in public education, led by the City Council, the Provincial Deputation, and the Commonwealth of Catalonia. The Patronat Escolar, established in 1922, promoted secular, bilingual education and constructed numerous school buildings. Post-Civil War, education control shifted to the central government, returning to the Generalitat with democracy. Meanwhile, Nicolau Maria Rubió i Tudurí, in 1926, proposed a comprehensive green space plan for Barcelona, with concentric semicircles of parks and gardens between the Besòs and Llobregat rivers, and four levels of parks. Although his plan was largely unrealized, the city's green spaces expanded from 72 ha in 1910 to 450 ha in 1924. The 1929 International Exposition in Montjuïc further urbanized the area and built pavilions for the Barcelona Fair.

The 1929 International Exposition occurred in Montjuïc, leading to the urbanization of the Plaça d'Espanya, the avenue of Queen Maria Christina, and Montjuïc mountain. The construction of pavilions for the Barcelona Fair, designed by Josep Puig i Cadafalch, took place during this event. This exposition, lasting from May 19, 1929 to January 15, 1930, cost 180 million pesetas and spanned 116 ha. Montjuic mountain's landscaping was also part of the project, with Jean-Claude Nicolas Forestier and Nicolau Maria Rubió i Tudurí creating the Laribal, Miramar, and Greek Theater gardens.

Urban development in Barcelona was significantly impacted, not only in Montjuïc but throughout the city. Squares like Tetuan, Urquinaona, and Letamendi were improved, the Marina bridge was built, Plaça de Catalunya was urbanized, Diagonal was extended, Gran Vía was improved, and promenades of Gràcia and Sant Joan were developed. Public works, such as improved street asphalting, sewerage, installation of public toilets, and replacement of gas lighting with electric lighting, were carried out. Additionally, communication enhancements included the construction of Prat Airport, renovation of the France Station, improved suburban connections, elimination of level crossings, underground train tracks, and electrification of public streetcars.

The 1929 International Exposition in Montjuïc resulted in the construction of a funicular railway, a cable car, and improved public works, leading to increased immigration and the development of working-class neighborhoods. However, this also caused a rise in shanty towns and precarious housing. The first traffic lights were installed in 1929, with the Traffic Control Center opening in 1984. The Second Republic and self-government in Catalonia further promoted urban development projects in Barcelona, which was in need of infrastructure, housing, and facilities.

The Traffic Control Center, established in 1984 and managing 1,500 traffic light crossings by 2004, was a significant development in Barcelona's urban planning. The Second Republic and self-government in Catalonia spurred on various urban projects, as Barcelona, with a population of one million by 1930, lacked sufficient infrastructure, housing, transport, and public facilities. In 1932, the Generalitat commissioned the Rubió i Tudurí brothers to create a zoning project for Catalonia, the first attempt at comprehensive territorial planning. Another project, the Territorial Division of Catalonia, was carried out in 1936, dividing the region into 9 areas and 38 comarques, with Barcelona as the capital of Barcelonès. During this time, the Macià Plan (1932-1935) was developed by GATCPAC architects, led by Josep Lluís Sert and in collaboration with French rationalist architect Le Corbusier, further advancing Barcelona's urban planning.

The Macià Plan, developed by GATCPAC architects (1932-1935) with Josep Lluís Sert and Le Corbusier, was a groundbreaking urban planning project for Barcelona during a time when Catalonia had 2,920,748 inhabitants and 1,070 municipalities. The plan aimed to organize Barcelona into different functional zones: residential, financial and industrial, civic and service, and recreational (with parks, gardens, and beaches). A new geometric order would be established through large vertebral axes, such as the Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes, and a maritime façade defined by Cartesian skyscrapers. The plan also focused on improving facilities and services, promoting public housing, and creating a large park and leisure center near the Llobregat delta. Despite not being implemented, the Macià Plan is recognized as a significant milestone in Barcelona's urban planning history.

The Macià Plan, created by GATCPAC architects with input from Josep Lluís Sert and Le Corbusier, was a pioneering urban planning project for 1930s Barcelona, proposing functional zones and a geometric reorganization of the city. Although not implemented, it influenced later urban planning, particularly in the democratic period's focus on leisure spaces like the Maremagnum shopping center and Olympic Village. The GATCPAC also developed the Pla de Sanejament del Casc Antic (Old Town Sanitation Plan), promoting public health through urban renewal and municipalization of property. Additionally, they introduced pedestrian road signs and designed a workers' housing plan, the Bloc house, which was cut short by the Civil War. The Franco dictatorship (1939-1975) emphasized urban development, constructing subsidized housing for immigrants, but speculation remained an issue.

During the Franco dictatorship (1939-1975), Barcelona experienced significant urban development, marked by the massive construction of subsidized housing to accommodate an influx of immigrants. The city's population grew from 1,280,179 inhabitants in 1950 to 1,745,142 in 1970. However, speculation remained a problem despite the subsidized housing initiatives. Construction, often haphazard and with cheap materials, led to issues such as aluminosis. The housing developments, including El Carmel, Nou Barris, El Guinardó, Vall'dHebron, La Sagrera, El Clot, and El Poblenou, were primarily built on the city's periphery, which expanded to twice the size of the Eixample. This growth also connected Barcelona with neighboring municipalities, resulting in the "Great Barcelona" concept. The 1942 Municipal Ordinances reform, which allowed increased building heights related to street widths, further fueled real estate speculation.

The 1942 Municipal Ordinances reform, allowing increased building heights relative to street widths, exacerbated real estate speculation and disfigured Barcelona's urban space. Post-war urban renewal was led by Pedro Bidagor, who created the Barcelona Provincial Planning Commission and introduced the 1953 Regional Plan to integrate the city with neighboring municipalities, meet housing demands, and curb speculation. The plan, supported by the 1956 Land and Urban Planning Law, aimed for rational urban development and designated growth zones and green spaces, like the Collserola mountain range as a central park. However, many "partial plans" emerged, often succumbing to landowners' pressures and resulting in a 1.8x population density increase.

The 1953 Regional Plan, supported by the 1956 Land and Urban Planning Law, led to the development of new neighborhoods in Barcelona, such as La Verneda, Besòs, Les Corts, Collblanc, and others along the Diagonal avenue. This growth resulted in the construction of new markets and increased automobile traffic, necessitating improvements in the city's road network. The 1962 arterial network project planned radial highways and the construction of subway parking lots, while the Collserola mountain range tunnels were proposed, with only the Vallvidrera tunnel being built in two phases. Streetcars were replaced by buses, and trolleybuses appeared in 1941 but disappeared in 1968, as the metro network expanded.

The 1953 Regional Plan and the 1956 Land and Urban Planning Law led to urban growth in Barcelona, including the development of new neighborhoods and improved infrastructure. The water supply was updated with the addition of the Ter River, natural gas was introduced, and electrical and telephone networks were modernized. Barcelona hosted the XXXV International Eucharistic Congress in 1952, resulting in the creation of the Congreso neighborhood and its accompanying housing complex. The city also saw the opening of the Paseo Marítimo in 1957, as well as the establishment of the Zona Franca industrial sector. However, bureaucratic obstacles and the Civil War delayed its development until the 1960s. The Social Urgency Plan of 1958 addressed the housing deficit, leading to the construction of social housing in peripheral neighborhoods.

The Zona Franca project was proposed in 1900 by Fomento del Trabajo Nacional, with Guillem Graell tasked to lead it. However, various obstacles and the Civil War delayed its construction until the 1960s, when it was established as an industrial estate, not a free trade zone. Residential areas such as Casa Antúnez, Can Clos, La Vinya, and Polvorín were also developed there. In 1967, Mercabarna, a central food market, was set up, and in 1993, the Zona d'Actividades Logísticas was created. During Josep Maria de Porcioles' mayoral term (1957-1973), the City Council, empowered by the 1960 Municipal Charter, engaged in extensive urban development, creating large housing estates like Montbau, Southwest Besòs, and Canyelles. While some actions, like covering Aragón street and extending the Gran Vía, were positive, real estate speculation led to urban social movements driven by discontent with urban decay and political protest against the Franco regime.

During the urban development surge in Barcelona (1957-1973), some projects improved the city's infrastructure, such as covering Aragón street, extending the Gran Vía, and redeveloping the Montjuic seafront and Barceloneta promenade. However, real estate speculation sparked discontent, leading to "urban social movements" that combined frustration over urban decay with political protests against the Franco regime. Examples include opposition to Lesseps square's new layout and the Partial Plan of Vallbona, Torre Baró and Trinitat.

Plans for urban reorganization emerged, like the Master Plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona (1966), aiming to balance profitability and construction, and the Plan Barcelona 2000 (1970), focusing on infrastructure and acknowledging the chaotic urban growth. A utopian Universal Exposition project in 1982 was also proposed, with large avenues and a vertical axis linking Plaza de España with Vallès, but it was never realized.

The Vilalta Plan for wastewater treatment plant construction was approved in 1969, and the Plan de la Ribera (1964-1972) aimed to urbanize the city's eastern seafront, from Barceloneta to Besòs, by deindustrializing the area and building a megastructure of luxury housing blocks.

During the urban development surge in Barcelona (1957-1973), Antoni Bonet i Castellana proposed a luxury housing project for the city's eastern seafront, based on deindustrialization and consisting of seven large blocks. However, opposition from residents and professional associations led to its cancellation in 1972 due to alleged real estate speculation. The plan is now recognized as a step towards renewing Barcelona's urban planning in line with international trends. Meanwhile, during the dictatorship, green space efforts focused on maintaining and restoring existing areas, with Lluís Riudor and Joaquim Casamor leading projects like the Austria Garden, Monterols Park, Cervantes Park, and various thematic gardens on Montjuïc mountain. The end of the dictatorship and the arrival of democracy ushered in a new era of international avant-garde trends in the city's architectural and urban planning.

After the end of the dictatorship and the arrival of democracy in Barcelona, there was a shift towards international avant-garde trends in architectural and urban planning. The socialist councils of Narcís Serra (1979-1982) and Pasqual Maragall (1982-1997) prioritized urban planning and architecture as key features of the city. They initiated an extensive urban reform program, culminating in the 1992 Olympic Games, which included an increase in public facilities such as schools, parks, roads, and cultural centers.

A significant part of the municipal actions involved acquiring urban land, facilitated by the relocation of factories and industrial complexes outside the city. Oriol Bohigas was appointed as the Urban Planning delegate, leading to strong public investment in the city and a radical change in its urban physiognomy.

Urban change was driven by industrial restructuring, resulting in the creation of an Urgent Reindustrialization Zone (ZUR) as part of the Plan for the reindustrialization of Barcelona's center. The focus of urban planning shifted from expansion to reconstruction, with priority given to public initiatives and local needs. Public space interventions aimed to address quantitative and qualitative deficits, "monumentalizing" peripheral environments and promoting urban regeneration.

Lluís Riudor and Joaquim Casamor's green space efforts during the dictatorship, such as the Austria Garden, Monterols Park, Cervantes Park, and Montjuïc mountain thematic gardens, set the stage for the development of additional parks and gardens under democracy. These include the Mirador del Alcalde and Joan Maragall gardens on Montjuïc, as well as the Putget, Guineueta, and Villa Amelia parks in the rest of Barcelona.

After the end of the dictatorship, Barcelona's urban planning prioritized democratic values, international avant-garde trends, and public initiatives. The General Metropolitan Urban Development Plan (1976) aimed to curb speculation, rehabilitate degraded urban spaces, and emphasize social, welfare, and cultural facilities. The Metropolitan Corporation of Barcelona was established to oversee this plan, dividing the city into ten districts and implementing Plans Especials de Reforma Interior (PERI) for urban renovations. However, numerous lawsuits and claims delayed the project's execution, leading to its dissolution in 1985. Nonetheless, its guidelines significantly influenced late twentieth-century and early twenty-first-century urban planning.

During 1983-1989, the city focused on creating "areas of new centrality" to develop a more polycentric and well-connected urban fabric. By promoting various sectors of the urban periphery, Barcelona aimed to regenerate low-quality urban areas and decongest the city center. This approach was based on industrial restructuring, R&D, and new technologies, with an emphasis on public spaces, parks, and gardens. The green space efforts initiated during the dictatorship, such as Austria Garden, Monterols Park, Cervantes Park, and Montjuïc mountain thematic gardens, paved the way for additional parks and gardens under democracy, including Mirador del Alcalde and Joan Maragall gardens on Montjuïc, as well as Putget, Guineueta, and Villa Amelia parks in the rest of Barcelona.

After the dictatorship, Barcelona's urban planning focused on democratic values, international trends, and public initiatives. The General Metropolitan Urban Development Plan (1976) significantly influenced late twentieth-century and early twenty-first-century urban planning, even after its dissolution in 1985 due to legal challenges. From 1983 to 1989, the city aimed to create "areas of new centrality" to develop a more polycentric and well-connected urban fabric, focusing on industrial restructuring, R&D, and new technologies, with an emphasis on public spaces, parks, and gardens.

During this period, the city improved numerous road stretches and opened or refurbished squares, many with landscaping. Examples include Avinguda de Gaudí, Avinguda de Josep Tarradellas, Carrer Tarragona, and squares like Salvador Allende, Baixa de Sant Pere, and Sant Agustí Vell. Sectoral plans, such as those for Ciutat Vella, Carmel, Gràcia, Sarrià, Sant Andreu, and Poblenou, were also developed.

The "areas of new centrality" concept led to the delimitation of twelve areas, including RENFE-Meridiana, Diagonal-Sarrià, Tarragona street, Cerdà square, Port Vell, Glòries square, Diagonal-Prim (future Fòrum area), Sant Andreu-Sagrera, and four related to the Olympic Games: Montjuic, Diagonal-Zona Universitària, Vall d'Hebron, and Carles I-Avinguda Icària (future Olympic Village).

Post-dictatorship, Barcelona's urban planning prioritized democratic values, international trends, and public initiatives, leading to the establishment of "areas of new centrality" between 1983 and 1989. These areas focused on industrial restructuring, R&D, new technologies, and public spaces, with an emphasis on parks and gardens. Affordable housing policies were implemented, and in Eixample, block courtyards were recovered as green areas or public services.

The Pla Especial de Clavegueram de Barcelona (1988 and 1997) improved the city's sewer network, reduced flood-prone areas, and enabled beach recovery through breakwater construction. The arrival of democracy fostered the creation of new green areas, with gardens closely linked to urban planning, combining aesthetics, functionality, recreation, and services. Many parks were converted from municipal facilities, industrial areas, or former railway facilities.

The 1992 Olympic Games brought about another significant transformation in Barcelona, with numerous parks and green spaces established during this period.

After the transition to democracy, Barcelona underwent significant urban planning changes, focusing on integrating public spaces, green areas, and services. The establishment of "areas of new centrality" between 1983 and 1989 emphasized industrial restructuring, R&D, new technologies, and public spaces, with an emphasis on parks and gardens. The 1992 Olympic Games spurred another major transformation, as the city developed new infrastructure, sports facilities, and green spaces.

The Creueta del Coll park, built between 1981 and 1987, was created on the site of an old quarry. During the 1992 Olympic Games, Montjuïc mountain was remodeled, and the Olympic Ring, a large sports complex, was constructed. The Poblenou Olympic Village was built to accommodate athletes, and the coastal railroad was buried to make way for new facilities, such as the Telephone Exchange and the Meteorology Center. Additionally, two large skyscrapers, Hotel Arts and Torre Mapfre, were constructed, altering Barcelona's skyline. The Vall d'Hebron neighborhood was also developed, combining green areas with sports facilities.

Following Barcelona's transition to democracy, the city underwent significant urban planning changes, particularly in preparation for the 1992 Olympic Games. Two prominent skyscrapers, Hotel Arts and Torre Mapfre, were constructed, altering the city's skyline. The Vall d'Hebron neighborhood, planned by Eduard Bru, combined green spaces and sports facilities, and was the site of the Olympic Press Village. Several new parks and gardens were created, including the parks of Mirador del Migdia, Poblenou, Carles I, and three designed by Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay. The Old Port (Port Vell) was remodeled for leisure purposes, featuring the Maremagnum leisure center and the Rambla de Mar. A Coastal Plan was implemented to regenerate the city's beaches, resulting in cleaned and renovated beaches like Sant Sebastià, Barceloneta, Nova Icària, Bogatell, Mar Bella, and Nova Mar Bella. Sewage treatment plants were built on the Besòs and Llobregat rivers, and underwater reefs were placed to support marine life.

In preparation for the 1992 Olympic Games, Barcelona's urban planning changes included the renovation of beaches like Sant Sebastià, Barceloneta, Nova Icària, Bogatell, and Mar Bella with cleaned sand and underwater reefs for marine life. The Llobregat River was diverted, enabling port expansion. The Raval neighborhood was revamped, creating the Rambla del Raval and transforming Plaça dels Àngels into a cultural center with the Center of Contemporary Culture of Barcelona and the Museum of Contemporary Art of Barcelona. Technological advancements featured the construction of communication towers (Collserola and Montjuïc) and 150 km of optical fiber cabling. Road infrastructure expanded significantly, including the creation of ring roads around the city, led by Josep Acebillo and Alfred Morales.

The 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona spurred extensive urban planning efforts, led by Josep Acebillo and Alfred Morales, resulting in three new ring roads and the renovation of beaches and the Raval neighborhood. Additionally, a campaign called "Barcelona posa't guapa" focused on refurbishing facades and monuments. The successful planning initiative, characterized by harmony between social and economic agents, boosted Barcelona's national and international profile. In the late 1990s, urban planning shifted towards sustainability and ecological criteria, with an emphasis on creating environmentally-friendly public spaces and community facilities, as highlighted at the Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum in 1998.

After the 1992 Olympic Games, urban planning in Barcelona shifted towards sustainability and ecological criteria, focusing on creating environmentally-friendly public spaces and community facilities. The Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum in 1998 defined these criteria and emphasized the importance of public spaces adapted to the environment for residents. A notable achievement during this time was the promotion of the bicycle as a more environmentally friendly means of transport. The city also saw an increase in multi-municipal projects, such as the expansion of the port and airport, and the creation of the 22@ district in 2000 to revitalize the declining industrial sector in El Poblenou. The Urban Strategies Advisory Council was established in 2000 to assist the City Council in urban planning and strategic decision-making, with a focus on innovation, design, new technologies, and environmental sustainability.

After the 1992 Olympic Games, Barcelona's urban planning prioritized sustainability and ecological criteria, leading to the promotion of the bicycle as a means of transport and the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council in 2000. A significant achievement during this time was the creation of the 22@ district in the traditionally industrial El Poblenou neighborhood, which was in decline. The 22@ district aimed to preserve the business fabric of the area by focusing on companies specializing in new technologies. The 115 ha project was one of the most extensive urban renewal efforts in Europe at the beginning of the 21st century. The 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures further catalyzed urban changes, leading to the regeneration of the Poblenou neighborhood, the creation of the Diagonal Mar neighborhood, and the recovery of the Besòs area. The Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes is currently being remodeled to recover land for public use, and transportation has improved with the arrival of the high-speed train, expansion of the port and El Prat airport, and the reorganization of the bus network.

After the 1992 Olympic Games, Barcelona's urban development focused on sustainability and ecological criteria, leading to the promotion of bicycles, the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council, and the creation of the 22@ district. The city expanded its port and airport, aiming to become the logistics hub of southern Europe. The metro network was also expanded, and a bus rapid transit network was established in 2012. Additionally, infrastructure for pedestrian transit, such as elevators and escalators, has been installed in high and inaccessible areas. Green spaces, such as the Central Park of Nou Barris, Diagonal Mar Park, and Poblenou Center Park, have been developed. In 2015, a new urban master plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona was initiated, set for approval in 2021.

After the 1992 Olympic Games, Barcelona prioritized sustainable urban development, which included the promotion of bicycles, the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council, and the creation of the 22@ district. The city also expanded its port, airport, metro network, and bus rapid transit. Green spaces were developed, and in 2015, a new urban master plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona was initiated, aiming to classify metropolitan land, establish building regulations, define areas for sustainable development, preserve the environment, and ensure proper mobility. In 2016, a pilot test of "superblocks" began in Poblenou, restricting vehicle traffic and enhancing pedestrian and bicycle circulation, public transport, and public spaces. This initiative continued in 2020, focusing on the Eixample district, aiming to establish 42 new green axes and squares within ten years. Additionally, the first large dog park was opened in 2016, providing a recreational space for pets.

After the 1992 Olympic Games, Barcelona prioritized sustainable urban development, including the promotion of bicycles and pedestrianization. A new urban master plan in 2015 aimed to classify metropolitan land, establish building regulations, define areas for sustainable development, preserve the environment, and ensure proper mobility. In 2016, a pilot test of "superblocks" began in Poblenou, restricting vehicle traffic and enhancing pedestrian and bicycle circulation, public transport, and public spaces. This initiative continued in 2020, focusing on the Eixample district, with the first axis of action being Consell de Cent street. Four new agoras are planned, and one out of every three streets will prioritize pedestrianization and sustainable transport. Private traffic will be restricted to residents with a maximum speed of 10 km/h.

In addition, the temporary urban changes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to the creation of pedestrian zones using colored paint and temporary elements, with some areas designated for bars and restaurants. Many of these temporary changes became permanent, as seen in the new ordinance established in September 2021, regulating street furniture for hospitality establishments. These measures aim to comply with the Sustainable Development Goals promoted by the United Nations Organization.
